Mr. Harley outlined the options for NAEB in a new organizational
structure.
1 - NAEB could discontinue its separate incorporation and
become an integral part of the new organization, with
a Division and Vice President for professional services.
Constituency Advisory Boards could be maintained for
__ individual members, non-broadcast systems, and indus-
~~ trai 1/sustaining associates.
2 - NAEB could be maintained as a related but separate
entity.
He reviewed the advantages of an independent organization (even
without TV and Radio licensee members) as having freedom and
control of its own affairs, serving as a "conscience" and
advocate where required. Professional functions and services
could continue to the extent of their financial viability. He
also pointed out that NAEB may well not be viable outside the
new organization or would operate at such a low energy level as
to be ineffective.
The detail of Mr. Harley's observations is attached to these
Minutes.
Mr. Cannon suggested preparing a list of pros and cons from
other points of view, and indicated the need to keep in mind
that the immediate objectives Mr. Rogers wishes to achieve are
directly related to public television licensees.
Mr. Cordier spoke about radio's concerns in the development of
a unified structure. He indicated that radio station membership
was diminishing and that the NER Board considered three organizaÂ¬
tional options within NAEB and a separate option to move outside
the NAEB into closer alliance with National Public Radio. It
selected the option calling for continuation of the present staff
and a maintenance of current service, going in the direction of
serving the "Full Service" radio station. The Board also decided
to recommend to the members a change of the NER name to either
Educational Radio Services or Public Radio Services.
Mr. Harley indicated that Mr. Cannon's comments to him, as he
left the meeting shortly before noon, were to this effect: NAEB
would support the unified organization for public television
licensees but that we should seek assurance from Mr. Rogers that
he would support assistance to NAEB to cover the expense of
professional services previously contributed by television members.
